title: Antenna
subTitle: AI-Enabled Detection And Classification Of Insects At Scale
description: An interdisciplinary platform to upload, classify, and analyse in-the-wild images of invertebrates for research and conservation efforts.

intro.title: Introducing Antenna
intro.text: Antenna fills the data gap to help understand insects and protect biodiversity by enabling the scale-up of data collection with greater spatial, temporal, and taxonomic coverage than has ever been possible. It is an online platform where entomologists, ecologists, and machine learning (ML) and computer scientists collaborate to build trustworthy datasets by implementing and improving upon ML research designed specifically for real-world applications. Antenna cost-effectively and rapidly classifies a wide range of species in a large number of images, building a rich dataset that grows and updates over time.

intro.text2: Antenna currently focuses on moths but expansions to other insects are planned.

about.title: How Antenna helps
text: A billion insects for every human at any one time and 10 million insect species on Earth.

These estimates show how challenging it is to collect sufficient data, recognise observed species, and monitor population changes. Insects are key to ecosystems and agriculture, and severely impacted by climate change. Rich, quality data is critical to describing and responding to insect population patterns.

Antenna uses artificial intelligence to automate, accelerate, standardise, and scale up the identification of invertebrates in the wild. It performs fine-grained classification in large batches for species richness studies, new species discovery, monitoring of invasive species, and related applications. The resulting research-grade datasets comprise continuously updating information about the location, time, frequency, and quantity of species as observed around the world and are published to the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) using the Darwin Core Standard (DwC). Our technology is the most convenient and cost-effective way to enable monitoring at scale.

try.text: Due to our limited team bandwidth, we currently operate on a waitlist to ensure a quality experience for every user. Sign up below to join the waitlist and be the first to know when we expand capacity and receive our project updates.

help.title: Want to help Antenna?
help.text: To scale our AI, reduce wait times, and expand support for new insect orders, we are actively seeking funding and development partners. Your investment directly accelerates the future of global biodiversity monitoring.

aboutUs.title: Who we are
aboutUs.text: Antenna is led by a group of researchers and engineers from the Mila - Quebec Artificial Intelligence Institute with support from Espace pour la vie - Insectarium and technical contributions from scientists around the world (see Github repository for more detail). We gratefully thank Andre Poremski and Kent McFarland for their contributions in shaping the platform. We are proud co-founders of the Automated Monitoring of Insects (AMI) Consortium, whose mission is to empower local communities to protect and conserve biodiversity by generating labelled insect data at wide spatial, temporal and taxonomic scales.

citation.title: Citation information
citation.text: When using Antenna or the AMI dataset, please remember to give appropriate credit by including this statement: "Data processed using the Antenna Data Platform service available at insectai.org" and/or citing this publication: DOI 10.5281/zenodo.11358688.

questions.title: Do I have to contribute data to access the public dataset?
questions.text: No! The public dataset is available to everyone so we can collectively deepen our understanding of biodiversity and accelerate conservation efforts.

questions.title: What kind of invertebrates can you identify?
questions.text: Antenna currently offers machine learning models to recognise nocturnal lepidoptera (moths). However the platform is flexible and can support most detection or classification algorithms. Note that the default processing pipeline is best suited for sequential (time series) images that contain multiple insects. The organisms must be visually identifiable from the “above” perspective. See our Github repository for more information.

questions.title: How can I get and set up a monitoring station?
questions.text: The Platform is device-agnostic. You can buy and set up any type of camera, then log on to the Platform to upload and process your images.

questions.title: Can I use the Platform even though I am not a researcher?
questions.text: We LOVE citizen scientists! You absolutely can use the public dataset. However we are not quite ready to receive images from phone cameras. Until we are, you can check out our partner’s app Fieldguide and start snapping away!
